entry.title: Feasibility check on data migration approach from Pega Cloud to SAP BTP
entry.content:
Dear SAP Experts,

We are currently defining the data layer modernization strategy for a client planning to rebuild their existing Pega-based case management and workflow solution on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). 

The main ask from Client is if SAP BTP offers the same or better functionality to rebuild the CPPO Application with all the specification and implementation the client currently has available for the CPPO on ASPIRE Version.

Since the underlying PostgreSQL database in Pega is tightly coupled with the Pega application and not directly accessible externally, we are proposing a staged extraction and migration approach using the Pega BIX tool.

Below is the detailed end-to-end data flow and migration approach we would like SAP to validate for compliance and supportability within the BTP ecosystem:

Proposed Data Flow

  1. Source System (Pega Application):

    • Data to be extracted using Pega BIX tool in Database Schema output format.

    • Extracted data stored in Pega Cloud File Storage, as per standard Pega BIX process.

  2. Staging Database Setup:

    • Files from Pega Cloud File Storage transferred securely (via SFTP or equivalent) to a Staging PostgreSQL Database, deployed within the same hyperscaler region where SAP BTP is hosted (e.g., AWS, Azure, or GCP).

    • This staging environment will be used for initial validation, transformation, and reconciliation of extracted data.

  3. Migration to SAP BTP Data Layer:

    • Data from the Staging PostgreSQL DB will be migrated to the SAP BTP Hyperscaler Managed PostgreSQL service using native PostgreSQL utilities such as pg_dump, pg_restore, or pg_basebackup alongside psql (for data validation)

    • Target PostgreSQL DB in SAP BTP will act as the primary persistence layer for new SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) and SAP Build Apps-based workflow applications with CAP service as API interfaces to that persistency layer.

Clarification Needed

Can anyone please validate on the following points:

  1. Whether this external data ingestion and migration pattern (Pega underlying PostgreSQL DB ‚Üí Pega BIX tool ‚Üí Staging PostgreSQL DB ‚Üí Hyperscaler PostgreSQL in SAP BTP) is technically compliant and supported within SAP BTP guidelines.

  2. Whether any additional services such as SAP Data Intelligence, SAP Integration Suite, or SAP Data Provisioning Agent for better orchestration or governance in this migration pattern is required or only using PostgreSQL native utilities like pg_dump/pg_restore/psql is enough. 

BR,

Som

#Pega #SAPBTP #MigrateFromPegaToSAPBTP #HyperscalerPostgreSQLOption

entry.title: The Art and Science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build: Insights from SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
At SAP TechEd Berlin 2025, we had the opportunity to present ‚ÄúThe Art and Science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build.‚Äù The deep dive session explores how SAPUI5, SAP‚Äôs strategic UI framework, is transforming user experiences and developer efficiency across SAP. This blog post shares key takeaways from the session and questions from the audience.
If you‚Äôve missed it, watch the session recording in AD106v | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build.


The Art of SAPUI5 in SAP Fiori User Experience

SAP‚Äôs approach to user experience (UX) centers on making applications easier and more enjoyable to use, helping users accomplish their tasks with greater efficiency and satisfaction. The framework enables the SAP Fiori design system to evolve seamlessly across SAP solutions, providing flexible tools for developers to efficiently build apps using SAP Build Code.

SAP Web Components: Bridging Frameworks and Enhancing Extensibility

SAP Web Components extend the capabilities of SAPUI5, to other programming model, such as Angular, React, or Vue. This interoperability supports a consistent and streamlined UX throughout the SAP portfolio. SAP Web Components can now also be easily consumed in SAPUI5 apps just like regular controls. Going forward, SAP plans to provide new UI elements as SAP Web Components, minimizing the effort required for adopting new standards and ensuring compliance with SAP guidelines and modern Web standards.

SAPUI5 is leading is the Way in Accessibility

SAPUI5 is at the forefront of accessibility, with recent implementations (SAPUI5 1.136 and UI5 Web Components 2.9.0) aligned to the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2. This commitment ensures that applications built with SAPUI5 are inclusive and accessible to users worldwide, meeting diverse needs and regulatory requirements.


The Science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build

SAP Build is SAP‚Äôs unified solution to build apps and extensions, automations, agents and digital workspaces. SAP Build helps to increase developer productivity and to future-proof IT investments by leveraging proven technologies like SAPUI5, SAP Fiori elements, CAP and ABAP Cloud.

Extending SAP standard apps with SAPUI5 flexibility and Clean Core

SAPUI5 flexibility enables upgrade-safe, clean core extensions with intuitive low-code/no-code tools for different personas: end users, key users, and developers. New capabilities include consistent text changes for field labels and a ‚ÄúWhat's New‚Äù / ‚ÄúUI Adaptation Tour‚Äù for key users. Developers creating adaptation projects benefit from a "Replace original tile option and coding efficiency with TypeScript and Joule.

The new SAPUI5 runtime repository accelerates patch updates, improves startup performance, and supports zero-downtime deployments.

Future-Proofing apps with UI5 best practices and UI5 linter

Technical debt and legacy code can slow down innovation within SAP Fiori projects. Here the UI5 linter helps finding and fixing the usage of deprecated APIs and making your code is ready for upcoming SAPUI5 versions. The new SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 legacy-free version helps validating how compliant your code is to UI5 best practices, i.e. ensuring your code is state of the art and future-proof.

AI-Powered Development: Joule Copilot and MCP server

AI is revolutionizing SAPUI5 development. The Joule copilot accelerates app creation, view and control addition, code formatting, migration to TypeScript and much more. The UI5 MCP server enables agentic AI app development in SAP Build, combining generative AI with algorithmic logic if the UI5 linter.


Key Takeaways

  • SAPUI5 delivers a streamlined, consistent UX across SAP Business Suite, driving both user satisfaction and business outcomes.
  • SAP Build and SAPUI5 flexibility empower organizations to extend SAP standard apps efficiently, future-proofing their investments.
  • AI-powered tools accelerate development and let you future-proof your apps with UI5 best practices.

 

Selected questions from the audience

Q: Is Using VS code still recommended or the SAP Build for development

A:  In addition to the turnkey solution of SAP Build running on SAP BTP, SAP plans to focus on releasing development tools on the VS Code marketplace. VS Code is the number-one IDE worldwide, especially among web, cloud, and full-stack developers. Investing more in VS Code helps SAP meet developers where they are, making it easier for new developers to adopt SAP technologies (such as CAP, SAP BTP, SAPUI5, ABAP Cloud).

Q: New controls will be components from now on?

A: Exactly, SAP plans to deliver most new UI components as Web Components, which can be use across any Web framework, including SAPUI5.

Q: How AI compatibilities work in more complex application

A: Beyond Generative AI capabilities, agentic development tool (e.g. with the UI5 MCP server) offer impressive results for developing complex (fullstack) apps, from design up to deployment. You might want to check out Inside Joule: Lessons from building an AI coding assistant for SAP Build for an inside view.

Q: What is the benefit of using the Web Components from the example compared to sap.m.Input?

A: Please continue using SAPUI5 controls if they fulfil your needs. There is no change to that. Most upcoming, new UI elements will be provided as Web Component, serving *all* technology stacks, including SAPUI5.

Q: What are Components bringing when compared to Classic controls if we are using UI5 only approach

A: see above

Q: how will be the future scope of Fiori elements applications over ui5, do both will have same scope

A: SAP Fiori elements is an option to develop SAPUI5 app more efficiently. SAP recommends using as much SAP Fiori elements as possible and as much freestyle SAPUI5 as needed. This is what we do in SAP as well. Check out the SAP Fiori Development Portal on more details.

Q: What would be best approach to extend freestyle standard Fiori apps? Also, will adaptation projects have more extension powers?

A: SAPUI5 flexibility to the strategic way to extend/adapt SAPUI5 apps. The UI5 team continues to invest a lot in this area, as it is top priority for many partners/customers. SAPUI5 flexibility covers freestyle SAPUI5 as well as apps built with SAP Fiori elements. Adaptation projects offer best capabilities to create future-proof app extensions.

Q: Will the Build Code Joule CoPilot also support the Vibe Coding with MCP in the future?

A: Yes, SAP plans for vibe coding tools (incl. MCP servers) in SAP Build to empower business users to create application prototypes and start new SAP solutions without heavy coding knowledge.

Q: SAP develops SAPUI5 while promoting low-code tools like RAP, CAP, and key user adaptations. Isn‚Äôt it inconsistent to advance the core framework while encouraging less direct UI5 development?

A: Key user adaptation as well as metadata- / annotation-driven apps on RAP/CAP (using SAP Fiori elements) all use SAPUI5 as their UI technology. Innovations ‚Äòin the UI‚Äô are built in SAPUI5, benefitting all these models. Also, there remains a strong use case for a freestyle SAPUI5 implementation approach for apps which cannot follow the patterns of SAP Fiori elements.

Q: As a partner, if we build an SAPUI5 application and deploy it to customer systems, can SAPUI5 flexibility be used to create customer specific adaption projects for it?

A: This is planned for Q4/2025: Developer adaptation: enabling customer and partner applications for adaptation projects (As always with forward-looking statements, this is subject to change.)

Q: The build errors just prove you are really building live and not faking it. üôÇ

A: Right. Not sure though whether Tommy enjoyed the moment üòâ

Q: Now that CDS support UI annotations will UI5 become obsolete?

A: Definitely not. SAPUI5 remains SAP‚Äôs strategic UI framework. SAP Fiori elements with its annotations is built on SAPUI5. The annotations control what SAPUI5 is showing.

entry.title: Handling Record Count Mismatches After HANA Tenant Copy During S/4HANA On-Premise to RISE Migration
entry.content:
As part of a system move, We performed a HANA tenant copy from our on-premise S/4HANA system to the RISE environment. After completing the tenant copy, we compared the total record count of the SAPABAP1 schema using:

SELECT SUM(RECORD_COUNT) FROM M_TABLES WHERE SCHEMA_NAME = 'SAPABAP1';

Source Record count:

Target Record count:

A small difference appeared between the source and the target system.
To validate the result, We first checked whether any column-store tables were unloaded using:

SELECT SCHEMA_NAME, TABLE_NAME FROM M_CS_TABLES WHERE LOADED = 'NO';

No unloaded tables were found, so the values from M_TABLES were correct for comparison.

To investigate the difference, I exported and compared the table-level record counts.

The mismatch came from the following tables:

Table Name

Source

Target

/BI0/0K00193590

1

0

/BI0/0K00193626

2

0

/BI0/0K00193632

2

0

/BI0/0K00193575

1

0

All of these objects belong to the /BI0/ namespace.

Information provided by SAP clarifies that these objects are temporary BW tables, as described in SAP Note 2800007.
They are created during BW processing and are not persistent.
Additional related details include:

  • Hash / union temporary tables (40-character names)
    These store intermediate results for hierarchy queries. They are copies of 0BW:BIA:BI0* objects with a retention time. Unneeded tables are removed using BW cleanup tools such as:
    • Report SAP_DROP_TMPTABLES
    • Function module TREX_DBS_DROP_BW_UNION_TABLES
      Notes 2838176 and 2852066 describe adjustments and cleanup behaviour.
  • Temporary tables in the pattern 0BW:BIA:BI0*
    These hold temporary hierarchy or F4 help data. They are cleaned automatically or through report RSDDTMPTAB_DELETE.
    SAP Note 3316894 describes a case where automatic cleanup may not run as expected.

According to this information, differences in these temporary table counts between systems are normal and depend on BW usage and cleanup cycles.

Conclusion: 

The record count mismatch observed after the HANA tenant copy was limited to BW temporary tables described in SAP Note 2800007. These tables are not persistent and may exist or be cleaned up at different times in different systems. Because of this, small differences in their record counts are expected and do not indicate any issue with the tenant copy. The overall tenant copy can be considered consistent and successfully completed.

entry.title: Cloud-first, AI-Powered test automation in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
SmartBear participated in and won first prize at the ALMathon, the annual hackathon for SAP Partners. The challenge: Create innovative use cases to extend SAP Cloud ALM . So, we integrated Reflect, our AI-powered test automation product, into SAP Cloud ALM to enable users to automate their manual testing process.

Check out this demo to see it in action!

The urgent need for test automation

As organizations accelerate cloud adoption using RISE with SAP and as they keep up with frequent S/4HANA Cloud updates, testing early and often becomes essential. SAP‚Äôs own guidance highlights continuous delivery with frequent updates, which raises the bar on repeatable, reliable testing at scale.

Manual testing can be time-consuming, error-prone, and costly. It often becomes a bottleneck that delays releases and increases business risk. Studies have shown that embracing test automation can accelerate application delivery by up to 4√ó while reducing errors and risk. Teams moving from mostly manual testing to more automated approaches often save thousands of person-hours and cut testing costs by 25% or more. These benefits translate into faster, more confident deployments and fewer firefights in production.

 

A new approach to solving this problem

Reflect brings a cloud-first, AI-native experience directly into SAP Cloud ALM for test creation, execution, and results, while aligning with existing workflows that business stakeholders, IT leaders and software teams already use. Test creation, execution, and result reporting all happen within the familiar SAP Cloud ALM interface, so there‚Äôs no context-switching to external tools. Automated test results flow back into SAP Cloud ALM‚Äôs Test Management, so stakeholders can see pass/fail status and reports alongside processes, requirements, and manual tests.

 

Why is Reflect different from existing solutions?

First of all, there‚Äôs zero configuration, Reflect truly is cloud-first. No installations or browser extensions are required to start automating. There is no need to download any .exe files or Chrome extensions; you simply open SAP Cloud ALM and start creating tests. The solution runs entirely on a cloud platform, and all the heavy lifting (test execution engines, browsers, etc.) is handled in the cloud. There‚Äôs no need to set up local machines or maintain VMs for test runs because the infrastructure scales for you.

Reflect has no-code automation with AI-powered test creation, and there are two intuitive ways to create tests without writing a single script.

  • Record and play: This approach allows users to simply hit ‚ÄúRecord‚Äù and then interact with the SAP application (or any web/mobile app) just as an end-user would. The tool captures each action and creates an automated test without the need for any manual scanning of objects to create models.
  • AI-powered: This approach enables users to automatically generate automated tests from existing manual test cases documented in SAP Cloud ALM with a click of a button. This capability shortens the path to automating existing tests and makes it easy to build new ones from scratch.

Lastly, Reflect‚Äôs application coverage is broad. Reflect supports test automation for all SAP cloud applications out of the box. Whether you‚Äôre testing SAP Fiori apps, S/4HANA transactions, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, or any SAP application built with SAPUI5, Reflect can handle it. Reflect also supports non-SAP web applications and even mobile apps, enabling true end-to-end testing across hybrid workflows. In one platform, you get UI testing, API testing, and visual testing capabilities for web and mobile.

Reflects‚Äôs critical capabilities

 To further streamline test automation, Reflect provides several advanced capabilities that are worth highlighting. These include:

  • Reusable segments: Capture repeatable flows as reusable building blocks to speed up authoring and keep tests consistent
  • AI assisted self-healing: When the application UI updates or the underlying technology changes, tests continue to run, reducing maintenance effort over time
  • Simple and easy debugging: Users can troubleshoot their tests directly within the recording experience in case of errors vs going back and forth between the test modules and test execution
  • Execution suites: Users can create a playlist of tests using an easy-to-use flowchart, schedule them directly from the automation interface, and run as many tests as needed in parallel
  • Email and Slack notifications: When tests are complete, results are updated in SAP Cloud ALM, and users can configure them to be sent to their email, Slack, or MS Teams

 

Accelerate your SAP testing with Reflect

As SAP continues to accelerate its update cycle, organizations that can adapt quickly will be best positioned to succeed. By integrating Reflect's cloud-first, AI-powered test automation directly into SAP Cloud ALM, businesses can significantly reduce the friction associated with frequent updates. This integration enables teams to test earlier and more frequently, ensuring that their SAP environments remain stable and performant. With Reflect, organizations can achieve faster time-to-market, improved quality, and reduced testing costs.

Find us on the SAP Cloud ALM Partners ‚Äì Extensions page to learn more.

entry.title: Re: Error: Select a key from the allowed namespace. Messa...
entry.content: This error, "Entry with key outside of the namespace you manage," typically occurs in SAP when you are attempting to create a new entry (like a Partner Function or Partner Determination Procedure) using a key (ID) that falls within the SAP standard namespace (keys starting with numbers, or letters A-X), even if you are trying to assign it to a Z or Y (customer-specific) object. The solution is to ensure both the Partner Determination Procedure ID (if you're creating a new one) and the Partner Function ID you are adding to the procedure must start with 'Z' or 'Y'. If the Partner Function itself (e.g., ZP) is already defined in the customer namespace but you are trying to insert it into a standard Partner Determination Procedure (e.g., SM0001), you should check if the error is due to the key of the determination procedure itself. If you've ensured both keys are Z/Y and the error persists, it may be a configuration issue specific to your system's upgrade protection or a custom object in a non-standard namespace that you are referencing, and you should check the object keys and number ranges in the underlying customization tables (like V_TPAR for Partner Functions or the relevant view for the Partner Determination Procedure).

entry.title: In a World of Uncertainty, How Does SAP Help Leaders Stay Ahead?
entry.content:
In a World of Uncertainty, How Does SAP Help Leaders Stay Ahead?

Crisis Becomes the New Normal

Global supply chains wobble. Regulation and compliance demands increase. Markets change overnight. For CEOs, CTOs and CHROs, this shift demands fast action, not slow response.

SAP Tools Designed for Change

SAP helps leaders stay ready through:

  • Integrated data and systems: With SAP, different systems‚Äîfinance, supply chain, HR‚Äîlink up so decision-makers see the full picture.
  • Real-time insight: Data flows into dashboards fast, so leaders don‚Äôt wait for end-of-month reports.
  • Embedded intelligence and automation: AI and smart tools inside SAP solutions help reduce manual work and highlight key trends.

Why This Matters to the C-Suite

Speed, clarity and resilience matter. With reliable data, leaders make faster, more confident decisions. Connected systems and smart tools help organizations bounce back from disruption. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

Practical Leadership Scenarios

  • A CFO sees live cash-flow changes during a supply-shock and adjusts strategy next day.
  • A COO uses SAP tools to switch suppliers automatically when risk levels spike.
  • A CHRO identifies staffing gaps across regions via unified HR and operations data.

Key Actions for Leaders

To thrive in uncertainty:

  • Focus on data alignment ‚Äî ensure every function shares the same definitions and metrics.
  • Build governance ‚Äî with uncertainty comes risk, so traceability and control matter.
  • Promote a culture of agility ‚Äî teams must adapt quickly, empowered by insights not held back by tools.

Conclusion

Change isn‚Äôt slowing down; it‚Äôs speeding up. For leaders to succeed, the right systems matter as much as the right mindset. SAP provides the backbone. But it‚Äôs leadership that turns insight into impact.

Soft CTA:
If you‚Äôre exploring how your organization can build resilience with SAP solutions, join peer discussions in the SAP Community or connect with experts who are navigating change every day.

entry.title: Re: Configuration settings for automatic PS Project creation from PPM Item
entry.content:
Hi @bapats123 :  Thank you for your insightful question. Here‚Äôs my response:

For smaller organizations where a single team is responsible for creating PPM Items and PS Projects, it may be beneficial to select the Edit checkbox. However, in larger organizations with multiple departments involved in creating PPM Items, adhering to the PS Coding Mask for PPM Item IDs can be challenging. If the PPM ID does not align with the next available PS Project Code, the PS Project will not be created, and the system may not generate any error messages. This can lead to confusion for consultants who may struggle to identify the underlying issue. I recommend testing this in your test system to gain a clearer understanding of my suggestion.

entry.title: Marketplace App Deployment & Lifecycle Management Using SAP DevOps Tools
entry.content:
This thread is dedicated to exploring how teams can efficiently deploy, manage, and optimize marketplace applications using the SAP DevOps ecosystem. Whether you're working with SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP BTP, or integrating custom marketplace features into an enterprise environment, DevOps plays a crucial role in ensuring smooth delivery and continuous improvement.

In this discussion, I‚Äôm inviting the community to share insights, experiences, and best practices related to:

  • Automating marketplace app deployments using SAP DevOps pipelines
  • End-to-end lifecycle management, from development to testing, rollout, monitoring, and iterative updates
  • Using SAP CI/CD services for stable and compliant releases
  • Versioning strategies, rollback plans, and handling multi-environment deployments
  • Integrating third-party tools (GitHub Actions, Jenkins, Azure DevOps, etc.) with SAP landscapes
  • Monitoring & observability using SAP tools or external solutions
  • Managing extensions, microservices, and custom modules within marketplace ecosystems
  • Security, governance, and compliance across the deployment lifecycle
  • Common challenges teams face and how you‚Äôve solved them

If you‚Äôve built or maintained a marketplace app within the SAP ecosystem‚Äîor if you're working on improving your DevOps workflow‚Äîyour insights can help others in the community. Share your methods, lessons learned, tool recommendations, or even questions you're stuck on.

entry.title: Re: Customer Master Data - Updation in SAP S/4 Hana Publi...
entry.content:
Hello Chris1973

Hope you are doing well.

In SAP Public Cloud, the Migration Cockpit is often misunderstood when it comes to data changes. The Migration Cockpit only allows you to upload data.
You cannot update or change existing data using the Migration Cockpit (I‚Äôll try after your suggestion). This tool is strictly meant for initial data migration.

So, I am trying to use ‚ÄúManage Mass Maintenance ‚Äì Business Partner‚Äù

To update Business Partner data, you need to use the Manage Mass Maintenance ‚Äì Business Partner application.

However, you can only perform updates when the Mass Update Template is available within the app and that is where the real catch was. This was the point I had been missing during the entire process.

Before the Mass Update Template appears in the app, you must first enable the related activity in the system (from Implementation activity).
Once this activity is activated, the template becomes visible and you can successfully perform mass updates on Business Partner data.

I have now resolved the issue, and everything is working correctly.

Thank you for your support, and thank you as well for your helpful suggestions throughout the process.

Best Regards,

Tehreem Fatima

entry.title: Unable to start BTP ABAP Environment via Landscape Portal ‚Äì "System expected element 'object'"
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

this morning I tried to start my BTP ABAP Environment using the Landscape Portal, the same way I have done several times before. However, the environment no longer starts and instead shows the error message: System expected element 'object'.



When clicking Start, the portal triggers a batch request that fails with 400 Bad Request. The response payload looks like this:

{
   "error":{
      "code":"/A4CLP/MSH_MSG/000",
      "message":"System expected element 'object'",
      "@SAP__common.ExceptionCategory":"Provider_Application_Error",
      "innererror":{
         "ErrorDetails":{
            "@SAP__common.Application":{
               "ComponentId":"BC-ESI-ESF-GW",
               "ServiceRepository":"SRVD",
               "ServiceId":"/A4CLP/MNG_SYS_HIBERNATE_SRV",
               "ServiceVersion":"0001"
            },
            "@SAP__common.TransactionId":"61D0A68A790F482F85DBC57866695E9A",
            "@SAP__common.Timestamp":"20251117064124.696085",
            "@SAP__common.ErrorResolution":{
               "Analysis":"Use ADT feed reader \"SAP Gateway Error Log\" or run transaction /IWFND/ERROR_LOG on SAP Gateway hub system and search for entries with the timestamp above for more details",
               "Note":"See SAP Note 1797736 for error analysis (https://service.sap.com/sap/support/notes/1797736)"
            }
         }
      }
   }
}

The instance used to start without issues. Now the start operation consistently fails with this error.

Has anyone seen this issue before or knows what might cause this error? Is this related to Free-Tier environments, or is there any known outage or workaround?

Thanks for any insights!

SAP BTP ABAP environment

entry.title: Re: India: Export with Payment of Tax - eInvoicing
entry.content:
Dear Annika,

EXPWP (Export with Pay) is determined automatically for export invoices when taxes are calculated in the invoice. No special configuration is needed solely to set EXPWP.

If taxes are calculated in the invoice but are missing from the e-invoice XML:

  • Verify that ‚ÄúClassify Condition Types for Goods and Services Tax for India‚Äù is correctly maintained for the relevant pricing procedure.
  • Ensure all GST-relevant condition types used in pricing are properly classified so the tax amounts flow into the XML payload.

If the issue persists, raise an SAP incident under component CA-GTF-CSC-EDO-IN-IV and include sample invoice numbers, pricing/tax screenshots, and the generated XML payload.

Best regards,

Ravivarma

entry.title: How to Conditionally Hide Attributes and Sections in SAP Commerce Backoffice Using Dynamic Forms
entry.content:
Background:

SAP Commerce Backoffice introduced Dynamic Forms to make the Editor Area and wizard UI more flexible and context-aware. Instead of showing all fields statically, Dynamic Forms allow you to show/hide fields, sections, or tabs based on the current model values, without any Java customization.

This feature improves Backoffice usability and allows developers to control the UI using simple XML rules.

Problem Statement :

We want to achieve two requirements in the Product Editor Area:

  1. Hide a specific attribute (e.g., saturatedFat and unSaturatedFat) based on a condition.
  2. Hide an entire section (e.g., nutrition or manufacturing section) unless certain product properties are available.

How can this be implemented using Dynamic Forms?

Solution:

Below is a working configuration example that demonstrates:

  1. How to define the editor area for the Product.
  2. How to hide an entire section using df:section with visibleIf conditions.
  3. How to hide a specific attribute using df:attribute.

1. Editor Area Configuration

The following XML defines multiple sections in the Product editor area:

<context merge-by="type" parent="GenericItem" type="Product">
	<context component="base">
		<y:base>
			<y:labels>
				<y:label>code</y:label>
			</y:labels>
		</y:base>
	</context>

	<context component="editor-area">
		<editorArea:editorArea xmlns:editorArea="http://www.hybris.com/cockpitng/component/editorArea">

			<editorArea:tab name="hmc.tab.Product.detail">

				<!-- Product Basic Details -->
				<editorArea:section name="hmc.section.product.detail">
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="code"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="name"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="catalogVersion" readonly="true"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="approvalStatus"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="minOrderQuantity"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="maxOrderQuantity"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="showNutrition"/>
				</editorArea:section>

				<!-- Nutrition Section -->
				<editorArea:section name="hmc.section.product.nutrition.detail">
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="calories"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="protein"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="carbohydrate"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="cholesterol"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="totalFat"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="saturatedFat"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="unSaturatedFat"/>
				</editorArea:section>

				<!-- Manufacturing Details -->
				<editorArea:section name="hmc.section.product.mfg.detail">
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="manufacturer"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="dateOfManufacture"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="dateOfExipry"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="countryOfOrigin"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="seller"/>
					<editorArea:attribute qualifier="soldToCountries"/>
				</editorArea:section>
			</editorArea:tab>
		</editorArea:editorArea>
	</context>
‚Äã

2. Applying Dynamic Forms for Conditional Visibility

Hide a Section Based on a Condition

Hide Nutrition Section if showNutrition = false
Hide Manufacturing Section if manufacturer is null

<context component="editorAreaDynamicForms" merge-by="module">
	<df:dynamicForms xmlns:df="http://www.hybris.com/cockpitng/component/dynamicForms">

		<df:section id="nutritionSection"
			triggeredOn="showNutrition"
			qualifier="hmc.section.product.nutrition.detail"
			visibleIf="showNutrition==true"/>

		<df:section id="manufacturerSection"
			triggeredOn="manufacturer"
			qualifier="hmc.section.product.mfg.detail"
			visibleIf="manufacturer!=null"/>
	</df:dynamicForms>
</context>

3. Hide a Specific Attribute Dynamically

Example: Show saturatedFat and unSaturatedFat only when totalFat > 10

<context component="editorAreaDynamicForms">
	<df:dynamicForms>

		<df:attribute id="ProductSaturatedFat"
			qualifier="saturatedFat"
			triggeredOn="totalFat"
			visibleIf="totalFat > 10"/>

		<df:attribute id="ProductUnSaturatedFat"
			qualifier="unSaturatedFat"
			triggeredOn="totalFat"
			visibleIf="totalFat > 10"/>

	</df:dynamicForms>
</context>

Conclusion

Dynamic Forms provide a powerful and flexible mechanism to build context-aware, data-driven screens in SAP Commerce Backoffice. By leveraging df:section and df:attribute, you can:

  • Hide or show entire sections
  • Hide or show specific attributes
  • Create responsive editor areas that adapt to model values
  • Improve Backoffice usability and reduce clutter for business users

This approach eliminates the need for custom Java implementations and keeps the Backoffice configuration clean and maintainable.

If your project requires conditional UI behavior in Backoffice, Dynamic Forms should be your first choice.

entry.title: Integrate GitHub Copilot with SAP Cloud Application Studio
entry.content:
Requirement: 
To integrate GitHub Copilot with SAP Cloud Application Studio.

Introduction:
GitHub Copilot integration in Visual Studio Code offers powerful AI assistance for SAP Cloud Application Studio developers working on SAP C4C. It helps transform natural language prompts into ABSL scripts, automates repetitive coding tasks, and enhances logic building with intelligent suggestions. By streamlining development and reducing manual effort, Copilot boosts productivity and supports faster delivery of high-quality solutions.

Benefits of GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio/Cloud Application Studio

  • Supports complex logic building by offering real-time suggestions for conditional flows, loops, and data manipulations in ABSL.
  • Boosts productivity by reducing time spent on boilerplate code, allowing developers to focus on business-specific requirements.
  • Improves accuracy by minimizing syntax errors and offering context-aware completions based on SAP C4C development patterns.
  • Encourages collaboration by making code easier to understand and maintain, especially for teams working across different modules or geographies.

Sign In with GitHub Account:
STEP 1:
Click on GitHub Copilot -> Open Chat Window to Sign In

STEP 2:
GitHub Copilot login page will be opened. Click on ‚ÄúSign up for Copilot Free‚Äù

STEP 3:
Signup page will be opened. Click on ‚ÄúCreate an account‚Äù.

STEP 4:
Enter user details and create an account.

STEP 5:
Open SDK and click on ‚ÄúSign In‚Äù

STEP 6:
Click on ‚ÄúAuthorize github‚Äù

STEP 7:
User can access GitHub copilot now in SAP Cloud Application studio.

Open GitHub Chat:
GitHub copilot can be opened in two ways,

  • Separate Chat window.
  • Copilot assistant in script file.

1)Separate chat window.
Click on GitHub Copilot -> Open Chat Window

A copilot chat window will be open separately as shown below.

2)Copilot assistant in script file.
Open script file and click on ‚ÄúAsk Copilot‚Äù from the menu option

Copilot chat option will be opened inside the script file.

Start Typing with Comments or Partial Code:
CASE 1: ABSL Scripting Assistance
Copilot helps generate ABSL (Advanced Business Scripting Language) code by interpreting natural language prompts. Whether you're writing BeforeSave, AfterModify, or ValidationOnSave scripts, Copilot can suggest logic structures, syntax, and even error handling patterns, reducing development time and minimizing syntax errors.
Example:

  • Prompt: ‚Äúwrite code to raise an error message, if the email ID is testmail@gmail.com‚Äù

Prompt response:

CASE 2 : Review and refine code
If you're working with legacy or repetitive code, Copilot can help refactor loops, simplify conditions, and remove redundancy. It acts like a virtual reviewer, offering cleaner alternatives and improving overall code quality.
Example:

  • Prompt:‚Äù Identify the lines of code which has dump issues and fix it.‚Äù

    In below screen shot Copilot Identified the inconsistent lines in red and provided fix/suggestions in green color.

Prompt response:

CASE 3: To Explain the code
GitHub Copilot uses AI to understand the context of your code and comments, offering real-time suggestions and explanations. It would help the developers in understanding the code quickly, there by saving the time and efforts for analysis.
Example:

  • Prompt: Explain me the selected lines of code

Prompt response:

  • Prompt: Explain me the code in the script file

Prompt response:

CASE 4: Basic syntax generation
GitHub Copilot can help developers working in SAP Cloud Application Studio by generating basic ABSL (Advanced Business Scripting Language) syntax. It understands the context of business objects and actions, offering ready-to-use code snippets like variable declarations, loops, and conditional statements. This accelerates development and reduces errors, especially for those new to ABSL.

Conclusion:
Using GitHub Copilot in SAP C4C development streamlines coding by offering intelligent suggestions tailored to the platform‚Äôs scripting and extension needs. It boosts developer productivity by reducing repetitive tasks and helping maintain clean, consistent code. Copilot also serves as a valuable learning aid for those new to SAP C4C, guiding them through SDK usage and integration patterns.

entry.title: OData Service: ‚ÄúNo system alias found for service‚Äù after transport to QA ‚Äì why is ‚ÄúLOCAL‚Äù missing?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôve created an OData service that reads data from a custom table and provides PDF downloads. Everything is fully implemented and working in our development system (DEV). The service also runs fine in the Gateway Client (/IWFND/GW_CLIENT).

After transporting it to QA, I‚Äôm getting the following error in the Gateway Client:

500 ‚Äì No system alias found for service

When I checked the service in QA via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE, I noticed that there is no system alias ‚ÄúLOCAL‚Äù defined at all.

This confused me because in DEV the service is assigned to the alias ‚ÄúLOCAL‚Äù, but in QA it doesn‚Äôt exist.

What also makes it strange:

Other OData services in QA and PROD are working fine‚Äîeven though they also don‚Äôt have any system alias assigned. So the system somehow works without explicitly having ‚ÄúLOCAL‚Äù configured.

My questions:

Why does ‚ÄúLOCAL‚Äù exist in DEV but not in QA/PROD?

Shouldn‚Äôt this be consistent?

How is it possible that other OData services work without any system alias at all?

Is the system using some kind of implicit local alias?

What is the correct way to fix this issue for my new OData service?

Do I need to create the alias manually in QA, or is there a better approach?

How can I make sure that existing productive OData services won‚Äôt be affected by this configuration?

entry.title: Re: What's new in SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Hi @LaurinPS , SAP Logistics Management is a separate, completely new product built on SAP BTP with a micro services based architecture. It currently connects with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition via purchase orders and outbound deliveries. In SAP Logistics Management, we also have warehouse tasks in order to execute for example putaway movements. These warehouse tasks are within SAP Logistics Management and not transferred externally, also not to SAP EWM. So no, they are not visible in /scwm/ordim_o or via the warehouse management monitor but you can see them in SAP Logistics Management for example via the app Process Warehouse Tasks. 

Hope this helps. Kind Regards,

Nadine

entry.title: Extending Form Templates for Sales Document Output
entry.content:
In Sales, you often need to create output for sales documents (for example, printed sales orders) or share document output via email. To meet these requirements, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides the Output Management Framework, which enables documents to be printed as PDFs or sent electronically. SAP delivers preconfigured form templates and gateway services for each type of sales document. 

However, the fields available in the predelivered form templates may not always fulfill specific customer needs. In such cases, you can enhance the services to include additional fields and customize form templates accordingly. Before implementing any enhancement, check whether the desired field already exists in the predelivered form templates in the Maintain Form Templates app. 

Here are some examples of form template customization: 

  • Extend predelivered forms with additional partner functions 
  • Extend predelivered forms with additional condition types 
  • Extend predelivered forms with additional standard fields 
  • Extend predelivered forms with custom fields 

 

Extend Predelivered Forms with Additional Partner Functions 

The predelivered form templates support four partner functions:  

  • AG: Sold-to party 
  • WE: Ship-to party 
  • RE: Bill-to party 
  • RG: Payer 

Output data includes the country, address, language of correspondence for the address, and the partner's full name. 

You can include additional partner functions (e.g., sales employee) in your custom form templates (that is, copies of the predelivered form templates). For more information, see How to Enable Printing of Partner Function-Specific Information. 

Note: The fields available for the output are hardcoded and fixed. 

 

Extend Predelivered Forms with Additional Condition Types 

You can enable additional condition types in your custom form templates. Complete the following steps: 

Identify the relevant pricing procedure used in the sales document. 

Open the sales document and check the information in the document header. 

In your configuration environment, open the configuration activity Set Pricing Procedures (101117) and make settings for the target condition types in "Procedures-Control Data". 

Example: For condition type PPR0, enter a or A in the Print Type column.  

  • Lowercase (a): Item-Level condition data is relevant. 
  • Uppercase (A): Header-Level condition data is relevant. 

(Optional) Add calculation logic in the form template using scripting. 

For example, to get a subtotal of two condition types, you can add a script to perform this calculation within the custom form template. This allows for dynamic adjustments and tailored outputs based on specific business needs. 

 

Extend Predelivered Forms with Additional Standard Fields 

Some standard fields (for example, customer group) are not available in the predelivered form templates by default. You can enable these standard fields in your custom form templates via data source extension in the Custom Fields app. 

For example, for sales orders, you can create a data source extension for the Sales: Sales Order Confirmation Form (FDP_V1_ORDER_CONFIRM_SRV) form service in the Custom Fields app. As shown below, you can select fields from the list. 

Note:  

  • This extension approach does not support the fields on schedule line level. 
  • Some fields added via data source extension may not appear in PDF preview but will show in the final output.  

For more information, see How to Extend a Custom Form Template with Standard Fields. 

 

Extend Predelivered Forms with Custom Fields 

You can extend your custom forms templates (that is, copies of the predelivered form templates) with custom fields created in the Custom Fields app. 

Complete the following steps in the Custom Fields app: 

Create custom fields in the following business contexts: 

  • Sales: Sales Document 
  • Sales: Sales Document Item 

Enable usage of the custom fields under Form Templates for the respective form templates. 

Note: When you use the following BAdIs to set or change values of custom fields in sales documents, do not use CDS views as input data in your custom logic: 

  • Modification of Header Custom Fields in Sales Documents (SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM) 
  • Modification of Header Custom Fields in Sales Documents (SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD) 

Instead, you should use the input parameters of the BAdIs in your custom logic. This ensures real-time transactional data in document output. 

For more information, see How to Extend a Custom Form Template with Custom Fields.

Dear Team,

Thank you for your query.

We reviewed the Monitor Purchase Requisition Items application and confirmed that, in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the system does not provide any BADI or extensibility option to add additional fields such as PR/PO approver details, approval timestamps, or PO references directly into this standard app.

This application is built on a standard analytical data model that cannot be modified through enhancements or UI extensions.

Recommended and Supported Approach

Kindly explore the CDS views : SAP Business Accelerator Hub 

Summary

Since the standard app cannot be enhanced, the custom analytical report approach is the recommended method to deliver all required additional fields in a compliant and upgrade-safe way.

The following cases are classified as consulting requests and should not be raised via a Support incident. This includes inquiries concerning:

    1. Advice or assistance relating to configuration, business process analysis, or implementation specific to the customer‚Äôs unique environment or already documented in Product Guides.
    2. ‚ÄòHow-To‚Äô questions seeking assistance with documented features.
    3. Assistance with customization of the core product, core functionality and/or problems or errors caused by customization that has been implemented or completed by customers or partners.

Best Regards, 
Aishwarya

entry.title: SAP-RPT-1: A Revolutionary Tabular ML Model and OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance
entry.content:
Note: This blog discusses SAP-RPT-1 model, the enterprise version of the ConTextTab / SAP-RPT-1-OSS model architecture. The underlying technology is detailed in the ConTextTab research paper published by SAP, with an open-source implementation available as ConTextTab on Hugging Face and GitHub.

The Challenge: Traditional Tabular ML's Security Dilemma

In the world of enterprise machine learning, tabular data represents the backbone of business intelligence from customer analytics to financial forecasting. However, traditional tabular ML approaches have long faced a fundamental security challenge: the need for extensive fine-tuning on customer data.

When organisations deploy conventional ML models, they must:
- Fine-tune models using sensitive customer data, permanently modifying model weights
- Store customer information within model parameters, creating privacy risks
- Manage complex security frameworks to protect against data poisoning, model inversion, and membership inference attacks
- Navigate compliance requirements while maintaining model performance

This creates a paradox: the more effective the model becomes through fine-tuning, the greater the security risks it introduces.

Enter SAP-RPT-1: Redefining Tabular Machine Learning

The Breakthrough: In-Context Learning for Tabular Data

SAP-RPT-1 represents a paradigm shift in tabular machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. Built on the principle of In-Context Learning (ICL), SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance without ever modifying its core model weights.

How SAP-RPT-1 Works: A Security-First Architecture

Unlike traditional models that require fine-tuning, SAP-RPT-1 operates through a fundamentally different mechanism:

  1. Customer provides data (tables) examples as context
  2. Model processes examples in real-time without storing or learning from them
  3. Predictions are made based on patterns identified in the provided context
  4. Customer data is immediately discarded after prediction completion

This approach delivers two critical advantages:
- Superior performance through semantic understanding of tabular relationships
- Inherent security advantages through its ephemeral processing approach, addressing several traditional ML vulnerability categories.

The Technical Innovation: Seven Pillars of Security-by-Design

SAP-RPT-1 revolutionary approach is built on seven fundamental characteristics that naturally eliminate most machine learning security risks:

1. Specialized Architecture for Tabular Data

SAP-RPT-1 is fundamentally a classification and regression model designed specifically for structured data, not a Large Language Model. This focus makes it subject to the OWASP ML Top 10 security framework rather than LLM-specific vulnerabilities, providing a clearer security assessment pathway.

2. In-Context Learning vs. Traditional Fine-Tuning

The core innovation lies in SAP-RPT-1 learning approach:
- Traditional Fine-tuning: Permanently modifies model weights using customer data, creating persistent security risks
- SAP-RPT-1 ICL: Uses customer data as contextual examples within the input, without modifying any model parameters
- Security Advantage: Eliminates risks associated with model weight manipulation and data persistence

3. Enterprise API-First Security Model

- Fully managed API service: SAP handles all infrastructure, security, and model management while customers interact exclusively through secure, authenticated API endpoints
-  Enterprise-grade security: Leverages SAP's proven security frameworks and compliance standards to safeguard SAP-RPT-1, while the base architecture remains transparently published through the open-source SAP-RPT-1-OSS version
- Controlled environment: All predictions occur within SAP's secure infrastructure

4. Customer Data Dependency as a Security Feature

SAP-RPT-1 ICL architecture creates an inherent security advantage:
- No standalone inference: Model requires customer-provided historical examples for every prediction
- Customer data control: Prediction quality directly depends on customer-provided context
- Reduced poisoning risk: Traditional attacks like model poisoning and data poisoning become significantly limited
- Contextual relevance: Model can only make predictions within the scope of provided examples

 5. Ephemeral Processing Architecture

Every SAP-RPT-1 inference follows a secure, temporary processing model:
- Memory-only processing: Customer data exists solely during the inference request
- No weight updates: Model parameters remain completely unchanged throughout operation
- Zero persistence: No traces of customer information remain in the model

6. Enterprise-Grade SAP Management

As a SAP-provided service, SAP-RPT-1 benefits from comprehensive enterprise security controls:
- Supply chain security: Direct SAP control over model development, training, and distribution
- Model integrity: Protection against unauthorised modifications and tampering
- Data governance & compliance:   SAP ensures that all data used to train its Foundation Model follows strict regulations to protect privacy and meet legal standards. SAP has robust security policies to manage data safely when developing its applications.
- Quality assurance: Professional model validation and continuous security testing

7. Secure Semantic Processing Pipeline

SAP-RPT-1 employs a mathematically based data processing approach that eliminates code execution risks:

All inputs (strings, numbers, dates, etc.) are transformed into embeddings (vector representations of the data), and these embeddings undergo pure mathematical transformations within the model with no code execution occurring during data processing, only mathematical operations on numerical vectors: Inputs (e.g., strings, numbers, dates) ‚Üí Vector Embeddings ‚Üí Mathematical Operations ‚Üí Prediction Result.

Security guarantees:
- No code execution pathways in data processing
- Pure mathematical tensor operations throughout the pipeline
- Semantic understanding without security vulnerabilities
- Input sanitization through numerical conversion

SAP-RPT-1 & OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance

With SAP-RPT-1 architecture established, we can now examine how these design principles address the industry-standard OWASP ML Top 10 security framework. This assessment demonstrates that SAP-RPT-1 innovative approach doesn't just match traditional security measures, it fundamentally eliminates most attack vectors entirely.

SAP RPT-1 & OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance Overview

OWASP ML Top 10Risk Applicability to SAP RPT-1Risk Assessment Technical RationaleSecurity Status
ML01: Input Manipulation AttackApplicableMinimal exposure due to customer-controlled data model

Customers provide their own contextual examples, significantly reducing adversarial input scenarios. Risk limited to compromised customer environments.

Customer Managed
ML02: Data Poisoning AttackNot ApplicableArchitecture prevents traditional data poisoning

In-Context Learning does not modify model weights. Customer data serves only as contextual input during inference, with no persistent model updates.

Inherently Protected
ML03: Model Inversion AttackNot ApplicableNo sensitive training data to extractCustomer data is ephemeral and not embedded in model weights. No gradient information exposed through API.Inherently Protected
ML04: Membership Inference AttackNot ApplicableSAP regulated training data eliminates attack vectorNo customer data persists in model, eliminating membership inference opportunities.Inherently Protected
ML05: Model TheftNot ApplicableSAP-managed infrastructure prevents model parameter accessSAP-RPT-1 is provided and managed within SAP's secure infrastructure. Customers access only the API endpoint, never the model parameters . Further since customer provided context is not saved in model due to ICL, model theft has no impact on customersInherently Protected
ML06: AI Supply Chain AttacksNot ApplicableSAP as trusted model provider eliminates supply chain riskSAP is the official model provider with direct control over development, training, and distribution. No third-party supply chain vulnerabilities.Inherently Protected
ML07: Transfer Learning AttackNot ApplicableNo transfer learning in deployment architectureIn-Context Learning eliminates transfer learning attack vectors entirely..Inherently Protected
ML08: Model Skewing ApplicableCustomer data quality responsibilityPotential for unintentional bias in customer-provided data. Model leverages  patterns present in contextual examples, requiring customer awareness and data curation.Customer Managed
ML09: Output Integrity AttackApplicableStandard API security controls applyRisk can be mitigated through conventional authentication and authorization mechanisms.Customer Managed
ML10: Model PoisoningNot ApplicableImmutable model architecturePre-trained model weights remain completely unchanged during operation. Customer data cannot modify base model behaviour or parameters.Inherently Protected

The Results: A New Standard for Secure ML

SAP-RPT-1 Security Achievement

The OWASP ML Top 10 compliance reveals SAP-RPT-1 remarkable security profile:

Inherent Protection Against 7 out of 10 Major Threats
SAP-RPT-1 In-Context Learning architecture provides built-in protection against most ML security risks. Unlike traditional systems that require extensive security hardening, SAP-RPT-1 design reduces the likelihood of most attack vectors by default.

Standard Controls for Remaining Risks
The three-remaining low-risk areas (Input Manipulation, Model Skewing, and Output Integrity) are addressed through conventional security measures that organisations typically already have in place:
- Input validation and API security controls
- Customer data governance
- Standard authentication and authorization mechanisms

Customer Empowerment Through Data Control
Rather than creating security burdens, SAP-RPT-1 empowers customers by giving them direct control over model behaviour through their own data, while eliminating the risks associated with traditional model training.

References:
- OWASP ML Security Top 10
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Paper
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Model
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Github
- SAP-RPT-1 Model FAQ
- Know more on SAP-RPT-1 Model

entry.title: Re: Output tax field in the customer master.
entry.content:
For information, tax determination is not controlled directly by fields in the customer master. Instead, it is driven by Tax Departure Country/Region (Dep. Country/Region) ‚Üí taken from the supplying plant or company code, Customer‚Äôs destination country/region ‚Üí taken from the customer master (address data) and Tax condition records ‚Üí maintained in Manage Tax Records app. The ‚ÄúOutput Tax‚Äù field you see in the customer master is essentially a tax classification indicator, not a place to add new countries.

In order to add another Country/Region, in your case, it is US, Go to Manage Your Solution ‚Üí Configure Tax on Sales and Purchases. Add the US as a departure country/region for tax determination. In the Business Partner (Customer Master), under Sales and Distribution ‚Üí Billing ‚Üí Output Tax, you can assign tax classifications per country/region. If you want to see ‚ÄúUS‚Äù appear here, you must first configure the tax departure country/region in SSCUI. Use the Manage Tax Records app to define tax codes for the US. Link them to the departure country/region and customer tax classification.

entry.title: Re: fixed quantity indicator in standard costing estimate
entry.content:
Yes why this happens is because, Costing explosion in CK11N follows the quantity structure of BOMs and routings. For fixed‚Äëquantity components, costing only respects the flag if the component is directly under the costed material‚Äôs BOM. When the fixed‚Äëquantity component is under a lower‚Äëlevel semi‚Äëfinished BOM, the system multiplies it by the semi‚Äëfinished quantity, because the costing run treats the semi‚Äëfinished product as a proportional input.

Options to avoid this issue are

Place the raw material directly in the finished product BOM (instead of under the semi‚Äëfinished). This way, CK11N will correctly treat it as fixed and not scale it with the semi‚Äëfinished quantity.

Run CK11N with a costing lot size = 1 for the semi‚Äëfinished product. This ensures the fixed quantity is applied once, not multiplied by the semi‚Äëfinished lot size. You can set costing lot sizes in the material master (Costing view).

Model the semi‚Äëfinished product as a phantom assembly (special BOM usage). Phantom assemblies explode into the parent BOM during costing, so the fixed‚Äëquantity component is treated as if it belongs to the finished product BOM.

@RomnickJohn 

You need to add the following configuration to package.json:

  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "TES_CWT_H_DEST": {
        "kind": "rest",
        "credentials": {
          "destination": "TES_CWT_H_DEST"
        }
      }
    }

Also, execute the following command to bind the destination service:

cds bind 2 <destinationServiceInstance>

Then, execute the service in hybrid mode:

cds watch --profile hybrid

entry.title: Re: What does "Price Category HF" mean?
entry.content: The item ‚ÄúPrice Category HF‚Äù in the BCPricingChanges sheet refers to Hotfix (HF) price category changes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. It is not a new functional field in the customer master or pricing itself, but rather an internal classification used by SAP to indicate that a Business Catalog (BC) or pricing‚Äërelated change is delivered as part of a Hotfix Collection (HF). In other words, ‚ÄúPrice Category HF‚Äù is a marker that the pricing change is tied to a hotfix release cycle, not a notice of future price category changes for customers. Have a look at this blog Understanding the Price Category information by @Tayane

entry.title: Re: How to dynamically split comma-separated values into...
entry.content:
I just tired this in SQL console in SAP HANA , you can try it in SQL View data sphere 

@archanareddy_2511 wrote:

I am working in SAP Datasphere (Data Builder ‚Äì Graphical View) and I have a column that contains comma-separated values inside a single row. Example:

ID

Observee(s)

19195

0039270, 0040932, 00051689

43400

00055233

121461

NULL

My requirement is to dynamically split these comma-separated values into individual rows, like this:

ID

Observee

19195

0039270

19195

0040932

19195

00051689

43400

00055233

I need a solution that is 

Dynamic (not limited to a fixed number of values like 5 or 10)

 Works in SAP Datasphere (Graphical View OR HANA SQL

Works even when:

  • number of comma-separated values varies per row
  • values sometimes contain spaces
  • column type is NVARCHAR
  • JSON_TABLE or STRING_TO_TABLE are not supported
  • Recursion is not enabled in Datasphere SQL View 
  • So far, I tried:
  • JSON_TABLE() ‚Üí not supported
  • STRING_TO_TABLE() ‚Üí not supported
  • Recursive CTE ‚Üí not allowed inside Data Builder SQL View
  • Regular expression functions ‚Üí no REGEXP_SUBSTR in Graphical View
  • Calculated Columns ‚Üí no built-in SPLIT or explode function

Is there any recommended Datasphere pattern for splitting CSV string fields into multiple records?

Is this possible in:

  • Graphical View (Projection, Aggregation, Calculated Column, etc.)
    or
  • SQL View using functions supported by SAP HANA Cloud?

If someone can provide either:

A working SQL example

or

A correct modeling approach in Datasphere

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

WITH source_data AS (
SELECT 19195 AS id, '0039270,0040932,00051689' AS observees FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL
SELECT 43400, '00055233' FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL
SELECT 121461, NULL FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL
SELECT 55555, '12345,67890' FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL
SELECT 88888, '0001,0002,0003,0004' FROM DUMMY
),
numbers AS (
SELECT 1 AS n FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 2 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 3 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 4 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 5 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 6 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 7 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 8 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 9 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 10 FROM DUMMY
)
SELECT
s.id,
TRIM(
CASE
WHEN INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n) = 0 THEN
SUBSTRING(s.observees,
CASE WHEN n.n = 1 THEN 1 ELSE INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n - 1) + 1 END,
1000)
ELSE
SUBSTRING(s.observees,
CASE WHEN n.n = 1 THEN 1 ELSE INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n - 1) + 1 END,
INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n) -
CASE WHEN n.n = 1 THEN 1 ELSE INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n - 1) + 1 END
)
END
) AS observee
FROM source_data s
JOIN numbers n
ON n.n <= LENGTH(s.observees) - LENGTH(REPLACE(s.observees, ',', '')) + 1
WHERE s.observees IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY s.id, observee;

We have already created a SAP CASE, but we haven‚Äôt received any solution yet . For now, expanding the SAP Datasphere parameters is ruled out due to its extra cost.

entry.title: üá©üá™ Build AI services using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and Generative AI Hub
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of Build AI services using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAP AI Core and Generative AI Hub. It is beneficial if you have some basic knowledge about JavaScript as we're using the SAP Cloud SDK for AI with the JavaScript variant.

This CodeJam introduces attendees to aspects of exposing generative artificial intelligence (genAI) capabilities to execute tasks using a given business context.

During this event, you'll become acquainted with the theory behind genAI, SAP AI Core, SAP AI Launchpad, and learn how to use the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model to expose AI capabilities through your own OData service.

While working through the exercises, you'll become comfortable creating CDS-based service definitions and integrating them into the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and SAP AI Core Foundation Models.

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday January 20th, 2026 in Bielefeld, Germany üá©üá™ from 10:00 am - 04:00 pm. The workshop site will be the Steigenberger Hotel Bielefelder Hof in Bielefeld. The event will be held in english.

The instructor is the Developer Advocate @KRiedelsheimer .

Prerequisites: Any Chromium-based web browser, such as Google Chrome.

Please note that seating is limited - we can only accomodate 25 attendees. Register here in the Community Event using the RSVP functionality.

For more information on SAP CodeJam events, to ask questions, and to chat with your fellow attendees, head over to the SAP CodeJam group.
